newsitem.title: USA: Newell acquisition may be accretive in '97.
newsitem.headline: Newell acquisition may be accretive in '97.

text.p: Newell Co's planned acquisition of the office products business of Rubbermaid Inc may be modestly accretive this year, depending on when the deal closes, a Newell executive said.
"It's not dilutive. It might be modestly accretive depending on when it gets done. That possibility exists," Bill Alldredge, vice president of finance for Newell, said in a telephone interview.
Earlier, Rubbermaid said it agreed to sell its office products business to Newell for $246.5 million.
Analysts applauded Newell's acquisition of the office products line, which had 1996 sales of $162 million.
"This augments recent acquisitions that they have made in the areas of office products," Everen Securities analyst Robert Craig said.

Alldredge said Newell has an "important presence" in the office products business, including through its recent acquisition of the Rolodex business unit of Insilco Corp. Rolodex markets office products, including card files, personal organizers and paper punches.
